definition: First martyr of education, knowledge, and philosophy
Coined "Eudaemonia", also known as "Happiness as life's goal"
"Know thyself", humility and intellectual honesty
Father of academy
Believed in the division of a person's body and soul
Claimed that the sould is divided into three parts.
Part of the soul related to desires and physical pleasures; satisfy
Part of the soul that houses emotions; courageous
Part of the soul responsible for reasoning; drive
Saint and Philosopher: "God is always with us"
"We are naturally looking for meaning and purpose"
"Born imperfectly... perfect"
Mathematician and French philosopher known as the father of modern philosophy
Modern dualism: Es Cogitans, Res Extensa
Thinking substance, refers to the part of a person that thinks, doubts, perceives, and understands
Extended substance, essense of physical matter. Part of reality that takes space and exists.
Proponent of methodical doubt
Systematic approach of doubting everything to establish a foundation for knowledge
"Cogito ergo sum" (I think therefore I am)
Emphasizes that being in constant doubt regarding one's existence is proof that a person exists.
Father of Classical Liberation
Proponent of Tabula Rasa
The human mind starts as a blank slate, which is filled with knowledge derived from experience either through sensation or reflection
Knowledge is ultimately derived from sensory perception and reflection on those perceptions
Scottish Philosopher who focuses on empiricism, skepticism, and naturalism
Self is the accumulation of different impressions and does not exceed the physical realm
Proponent of Bundle Theory
Suggests that the self is not a substantial entity but a collection or bundle of perceptions, experiences, and sensations
Gemran philosopher known for empiricism and rationalism
Believes that the awareness of different emotions, impressions, and behavior is only a part of ourselves
Immediate awareness of time provides the foundational framework for organizing our experiences of the world
Conciousness helps us understand and create a sense of self by putting together everything we've experienced, intuited, and imagined
Austrian, father of psychoanalysis
The provinces of the mind
Part of the psyche wich operates on the pleasure principle, seeking immediate gratification of needs, desires, and urges
Rational part of the psyche that operates on the reality principle; mediates the desires and constraints of the world
Internalized societal rules, morals, and values. Operates on the moral principle, allowing to behave socially and morally acceptable manner
British philosopher who believes that the behavior presented by the person.
Knowing how and knowing that
The way we act or behave can tell a great deal about our personalities
Canadian philosopher; "The self is defined by the movement of our brain"
Associated with eliminative materialism
Mental concepts might be replaced or eliminated by a more precise understanding of brain processes
French philosopher known for his work on existentialism and phenomenology
Coined phenomenology of perception
Unity of the function of the mind and the body
Follows "Gestalt Psychology"
Our perception of the world is intimately tied to our actions
Explained the compositioin of Man
Common stuff that makes up everything in the universe
Essense of a substance or thing
Will and Intellect
The soul is what animates the body; it is what makes us humans
Elevates a human being to a distinct level of existence
